title: 107_hr2616
content: The Act may be cited as the "Forty Percent Funding of IDEA in Four Years Act" or the "Forty-in-Four Act". Congress finds that while the Federal Government requires States to provide free appropriate public education to children with disabilities under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, it has never contributed more than 14.9 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure, despite committing to up to 40 percent. Fully funding the Act would help States and local educational agencies with the excess costs of educating children with disabilities. The Act aims to provide 40 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure by 2005 to assist States and local educational agencies with the excess costs of educating children with disabilities under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. This would allow for resources to reduce class size, improve school facilities, provide tax relief, and address local needs. The grant amount for states under Part B of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is specified in Section 3. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act specifies the minimum grant amount for states based on the number of children with disabilities receiving special education services and the average per-pupil expenditure in public schools. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act specifies grant amounts for states based on the number of children with disabilities and per-pupil expenditure. Amendments include increasing funding percentages for fiscal years and removing individual entitlement to assistance under state programs. Conforming amendments involve striking subsections in the Act. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to specify grant amounts for states based on the number of children with disabilities and per-pupil expenditure. Changes include increasing funding percentages for fiscal years and removing individual entitlement to assistance under state programs. Amendments involve striking subsections in the Act related to fund appropriation and reservation by the Secretary. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to specify grant amounts for states based on the number of children with disabilities and per-pupil expenditure. Changes include increasing funding percentages for fiscal years and removing individual entitlement to assistance under state programs. Amendments involve striking subsections in the Act related to fund appropriation and reservation by the Secretary, specifically in subsection (e). In amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, changes involve reallocating funds based on the number of children with disabilities and per-pupil expenditure. This includes adjusting funding percentages for fiscal years and removing individual entitlement to assistance under state programs. Specific changes include striking subsections related to fund appropriation and reservation by the Secretary. In subsection (g), amendments involve redesignating clauses and subparagraphs, adjusting funding availability, and removing references to fund appropriation. The amendments made by this section involve changing funding availability and effective date to October 1, 2001.
